2004 RMP Executive Summary

The accidental release prevention and emergency response at our facility

Our facility complies with the American National Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia with the exceptions stated in the Iowa Fertilizer law. It is our policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state, and local laws. If an emergency were to occur, it is our policy to notify the local emergency 911 representatives including the  local Fayette police, and Fayette fire department and the Fayette county LEPC (563) 422-6061



Our facility is a Grain elevator. We market, dry and store grain.  We sell anhydrous ammonia to farmers in the Fayette area. Our ammonia tank is a 131,000lb tank with associated piping, vents, and relief valves, check valves, excess flow device and manual shut off. We also have 20 nurse tanks that are also maintained and are included in the RMP Oty(lbs) calculations.



Our worst case scenario is failure of a 30,000-gallon storage tank when filled to the greatest amount allowed, resulting in a vapor cloud explosion. According to the EPA lookup tables the end point is 4.4 miles there is schools, residences, business and state parks within the distance to the end point, with a total population 935 people.



Alternative Release Scenario is a release of 2,900 lbs for a period of 2min. in duration. According to the EPA lookup tables the end point for this type of a release is .03 miles.



Administrative Controls

We fill our tank to 85% capacity as an administrative control.



The general accident release prevention program and the chemical- specific prevention steps. This facility complies with EPA?s accident prevention rule and all applicable state and local codes and regulations. The anhydrous ammonia system is designed, installed and maintained in accordance with state law.



Five-year accident history. We have never had an accident involving anhydrous ammonia that caused death, injurie

s, property or environmental damage, evacuations or sheltering in place.



The emergency response program. In the event of an emergency involving our anhydrous ammonia system, it is our policy to notify the Fayette Police Department, Fayette Fire Department and the Fayette County LEPC. We have discussed our system with the local emergency services and they have inspected our anhydrous system.

Planned changes to improve safety.   We are working on upgrading the anhydrous ammounia nurse tanks as they empty out, they will be painted and placarded.



Prevention Program for Program Two Facilities



Safety Information    Maintain information on safe storage and handling anhydrous ammonia. Maintain equipment specification for all equipment. Document SOP for the operation of the equipment.



Hazard Review        Use an industry standard checklist currently use

Exhibit 6A-4 from the RMP workshop. We also maintain the hazard review conducted by the

Department of Agriculture State of Iowa.



Operating Procedure    Implemented  employee training program

                Program complies with all government and industry 

                standards. Complete written operational 

                procedures.



Training             Implemented a safety program

All employees handling product will be tested annually. With refresher training done on an 

annual basis.



Maintenance    Maintain the on-going mechanical integrity of the tank. (from equipment vendors and industry codes.) We currently have a maintenance inspection checklist obtained from the RMP workshop.

    The schedule for inspection and testing of equipment will be done annually and we will document all inspections.



Compliance Audits    Pattison Bros. will conduct and document compliance audits every three years. We will send a report on the audits findings with a proper response to each finding. We will also document all corrected deficiencies.

    Pattison Bros. will maintain compliance audit reports for five years.

Incident Investigation    Pattison Bros. will investiga

te each incident that resulted in or could have resulted in a catastrophic 

release. The investigation will be started no later than 48 hours after the release. The investigation report will include the following:

Date of Investigation

Description of accident

Factors that contributed to the accident and any recommendations that resulted from the investigation.

Emergency personal contacted about the accident

Emergency personal that responded to accident

Date recommendations are implemented.

Safety, maintenance, hazard review and training procedures that have been changed due to the accident.



A catastrophic release is one that presents an imminent and substantial endangerment to public health and environment.
